title.gco:CharacterString: Grayscale North America Shaded Relief 1-Kilometer Resolution

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States

otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: These data were downloaded from the National Atlas website (http://www.nationalatlas.gov/atlasftp.html) in August 2014.

collectiveTitle.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

abstract.gco:CharacterString: The grayscale North America shaded relief data were derived from the GTOPO30 elevation data. GTOPO30 is a global digital elevation model (DEM) with a horizontal grid spacing of 30 arc seconds (approximately 1 kilometer). GTOPO30 was derived from several raster and vector sources of topographic information. It was developed between 1993 and 1996 through a collaborative effort led by staff at the U.S. Geological Survey's Center for EROS. The following organizations participated by contributing funding or source data: the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), the United Nations Environment Programme/Global Resource Information Database (UNEP/GRID), the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), the Instituto Nacional de Estadistica Geografica e Informatica (INEGI) of Mexico, the Geographical Survey Institute (GSI) of Japan, Manaaki Whenua Landcare Research of New Zealand, and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR). This layer is part of the 1997-2014 edition of the National Atlas of the United States.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: The grayscale shaded relief image were developed to portray the terrain of North America. It is intended for visual purposes only. The original GTOPO30 data must be used for conducting analysis and determining elevation values.

credit.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States. (2005). Grayscale North America Shaded Relief 1-Kilometer Resolution. National Atlas of the United States. Available at: http://purl.stanford.edu/zz581px0362.

useLimitation.gco:CharacterString: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey regarding the utility of the data on any other system, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. No responsibility is assumed by the U.S. Geological Survey in the use of these data.

otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: This item is in the public domain.

title.gco:CharacterString: National Atlas of the United States of America, 1997-2014

environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; Esri ArcGIS 10.3.1.4959

supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString: The associated world file is included as part of the GeoTIFF. The contents of the world file are: >1000.0000 >0.000000 >0.000000 >-1000.0000 >-6086629.0000 >4488761.0000 The following projection file can be used when using ESRI's ArcGIS to view the GeoTIFF (any line breaks should be removed): PROJCS["NAD_1983_Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area",GEOGCS ["GCS_Sphere_ARC_INFO",DATUM["D_Sphere_ARC_INFO",SPHEROID ["Sphere_ARC_INFO",6370997.0,0.0]],PRIMEM["Greenwich",0.0], UNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]],PROJECTION ["Lambert_Azimuthal_Equal_Area"],PARAMETER["False_Easting",0.0], PARAMETER["False_Northing",0.0],PARAMETER["Central_Meridian", -100.0],PARAMETER["Latitude_Of_Origin",45.0],UNIT["Meter",1.0]]

gml:UnitDefinition.gml:identifier: Unified Code of Units of Measure

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: No tests for logical consistency have been performed on this map layer.
Data completeness reflects the content of the original GTOPO30 elevation data.

description.gco:CharacterString: The mosaic of elevation data used for North America Shaded Relief was first assembled in 1999 for use on the National Atlas web site, and for a printed color map at 1:10,000,000 scale published that same year. The original 1999 map layer was assembled from the following tiles of GTOPO30 elevation data: w180n90, w140n90, w100n90, w060n90, w020n90, w180n40, w140n40, w100n40, w060n40, w020n40. The tiles were ingested into Arc/INFO with the IMAGEGRID command. The resulting grids were combined into a single grid with the MERGE function. This grid was then projected into the Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection, centered on 100 degrees West, 45 degrees North. The .prj file used for the Arc PROJECT command contained these parameters: > INPUT > PROJECTION GEOGRAPHIC > UNITS DD > PARAMETERS > OUTPUT > PROJECTION LAMBERT_AZIMUTHAL > UNITS METERS > XSHIFT 0.0 > YSHIFT 0.0 > PARAMETERS > 0.0 > -100 0 0 > 45 0 0 > 0.0 > 0.0 > END > The western edge of the grid was extended to match that of the National Atlas of the United States Map Maker bounding rectangle, and the null cells in the extended area were converted to ocean color values using CON.

Using the Arc/INFO Polygrid command, a 0/1 land/water mask was created for North America, using coastline data clipped from the National Atlas shoreline file. The land/water mask was applied to the 16-bit elevation grid. The masked elevation grid as well as the mask itself is available on request. A grayscale shaded relief rendition of the elevation data was created with the Grid HILLSHADE command using these parameters: >azimuth = 315 degrees >sun elevation = 45 degrees >Shadetype = SHADE >Vertical exaggeration = 10.0 For access to the original 16-bit DEM data (Elevation2002), please contact the National Atlas.

In 2001 and 2002, some areas of the elevation mosaic were updated with improved data provided as internal files by science staff at EROS Data Center. The first update, in October, 2001 featured two significant improvements: 1. Much of the GTOPO30 coverage of the conterminous United States was updated from higher resolution elevation data from the National Elevation Dataset; 2. Parts of northern Canada were corrected to remove a processing artifact that created an artificial pattern of "dimples" in the shaded relief. These elevation data were used for a printed National Atlas product, the 2002 "Shaded Relief of North America" map published at 1:10,000,000 scale. In the second update, in September, 2002, data for Greenland were entirely replaced by a higher resolution dataset that, however, suffered from geometric distortion. These new data for Greenland were adjusted to correct for geometric distortion in the northwest part of the island between the Robeson Channel and Cape Morris Jesup, and to improve registration with the coastline derived from World Vector Shoreline (WVS). A link coverage was created in ArcEdit containing links between the original Greenland data and the new coastline. The link coverage was used in the Arc ADJUST command to perform a linear transformation with bilinear resampling on the original image, stored as an Arc/INFO grid dataset. The resulting image is geometrically correct and fits the WVS coastline. This correction was applied to data for Greenland only.

To set colors for oceans the grayscale shaded relief image was first converted to index color in Photoshop. Pixel value 255 was already reserved for water pixels, and so index 255 was set to rgb value (132, 193, 255), the blue color for oceans used in the National Atlas online Map Maker. Masked images from Photoshop were saved as TIFF's, then ingested into Arc/INFO's Grid module, saved as TIFF's from Arc/INFO, and then processed through a USGS GeoTIFF software program to create fully- compliant GeoTIFFs with valid header information.
Shoreline mask for area of coverage.

title.gco:CharacterString: Shoreline file in Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection
